awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Mapping Regulatory Networks in Extremophiles
awd_abstract_narration:
1254754
Contreras

The PI proposes establishing new approaches for understanding and "reprogramming" RNA-mediated regulatory circuits in vivo. These not well defined networks are essential for the coordination of cellular processes in response to changes in environmental inputs and are vital for survival under high-stress conditions. It is proposed to map and characterize a regulatory network in Zymomonas mobilis using a method developed in the PI's laboratory and to investigate a model regulatory RNA that was found to differentially express based on oxygen levels.  The proposed research is scientifically significant because it will provide new fundamental insight into how large-scale molecular networks that involve both RNAs and proteins operate in the context of the cellular machinery.  

In addition, the PI will focus educational efforts on attracting and retaining underrepresented students to engineering by (i) creating a "Raising Future Scientist" program for students and their families, (ii) developing a new course to present bioengineering in the context of significant world problems, and (iii) continuing commitment to the existing undergraduate research program.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how living systems regulate the way that they respond to and tolerate environmental stressors continues to be of interest to fundamental biology and to applications in engineering. Although better understanding about these processes continues to emerge, a lot of these studies have been done in model organisms, where are a number of convenient tools and experimental methods have been developed. In this project, we seeked to identify novel regulatory networks in a nonmodel bacteirum, Zymmomonas mobilis, that is of interest to biotechnology due to its natural high tolerance to ethanol. Throughout the course of this work we have devolped tools that allow us to discover new regulators by predicting them computationally from large sets of collected data. We have verified that these regulators indeed affect alcohol tolerance in this bacterium and we have mapped and characterized some of the mechanisms that they used to exert these functions; Specifically, we have worked on understanding What (i.e. specific genes) that they regulate in cells. As part of this workm we have developed a suite of new fluorescence-absed tools to allow us to conduct these studies directly inside cells, where we can better assess native biological functions. Major biological lessons from this work include the synchronization of multiple pathways by the new regulators that we have identified, confirming that the ability to tolerate high levels of alcohol for living cells is highly complex and that it affects multiple cellular functions (that the cell regulates to protect). Technologically, we have been able to develop new experimental tools to study such mechanisms in cells (specifically related to interactions between molecules), where we are not limited to conducting these experiments just in test tubes without being able to fully capture all cell functions.

Another major goal of this work was to focus on educational efforts on attracting and retaining underrepresented students to engineering by: creating the “Raising Future Scientist” program for students and their families,  Through this program, we have been able to interact with over 100 families in our community. These families have reported overall increased positive attidues towards encouraging their children (who represent first generation college students) to pursue careers in science and engineering. Importantly, they have all reported a better understanding of these profession. The involvement of families in these discussions is often overlooked by STEM initiatives that aim to increase the number of students choosing STEM disciplines after high school and we have found these joint family discussions to be highly effective. This is now a well-established program that we plan to continue. 


Last Modified: 04/02/2019
Modified by: Lydia M Contreras
